repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Historical Materials Collection

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: University records are closed for 20 years from the date of their creation. Records older than 20 years that do not pertain to student education, staff and faculty employment and Board of Trustees records are open for research. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into six series: Artifacts and ephemera; Photographs; Books; Audio Lab materials; University audiovisual materials; and Unprocessed accessions.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Since 1955, Tufts University has continued to expand its horizons. In 1964, in one of Wessell's final acts as president, Tufts opened the Experimental College. The Ex-College, which allows students to take classes not normally found in the curriculum, has remained one of Tufts' most popular programs.

In 1977, Tufts established a five-year joint degree program with the New England Conservatory of Music. Soon after, in 1979, a similar program began with the School of the Museum of Fine Arts. Also in 1979, the Tufts Center for European Studies in Talloires, France, was established in an 11th Century priory. The Tufts European Center began operation soon after.

In late 1979, Tufts made another important addition. In October, the Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine opened at its original Boston campus. In 1980, the Grafton campus, built on the site of a state mental hospital, officially opened its doors.

The last two major additions to Tufts University took place in 1980 and 1981. In 1980, the Sackler School of Graduate Biomedical Sciences, established with a large grant from the Sackler family, opened its doors on the Boston campus of the Tufts School of Medicine. In 1981, at the Medford Campus, Tufts celebrated the opening of the School of Nutrition Science and Policy. The school was the first of its kind in the nation.

Since Tufts College was officially established in 1852, it has continued to grow and expand in new directions. From its beginnings as a small liberal arts college through its expansion into a full-scale university, Tufts has maintained a strong academic tradition and a community feel.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The materials in this collection have minimal provenance documentation. Digital Collections and Archives staff move objects from this collection into other more appropriate collections when provenance is positively identified.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Audio Lab materials series was re-processed in the Fall of 2014 by Tim Walsh, archives assistant, with supervision by Erin Faulder, Archivist for Digital Collections, using documentation from the original transfer. Accruals from fiscal years 2017-2019 were processed by Leah Edelman. Materials were placed in archival boxes if the original housing was damaged, and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. Received order was maintained. File or item =-level inventories were created, and series-level descriptions and the finding aid were updated at the time of processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains materials including artifacts, ephemera, memorabilia, ledgers, loose photographic prints, and audio and visual material relating to Tufts history for which no provenance can be assigned.

The Audio Lab series contains lectures, panels, conferences, and performances at Tufts circa 1960-2000. Notable speakers include Ralph Nader, F. Lee Bailey, Robert Klein, Maya Angelou, Noam Chomsky, George McGovern, Dr. Benjamin Spock, Coretta Scott King, Allen Ginsberg, Timothy Leary, Stokely Carmichael, William F. Buckley, Margaret Mead, Muhammed Ali, Jane Fonda, Joe Biden, Norman Mailer, Isaac Asimov, P.J. O'Rourke, Jimmy Carter, Haruki Murakami, Margaret Thatcher, and many other prominent social and political figures.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

did.unittitle: Tufts College Bonds and Trustee of Tufts College Dormitory Bond

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1926 Tufts College Bond for Roger Frederick Etz (A'09) was found with other un-cataloged historical items in July 2007. The 1926 Tufts College Bond for Morris M. Danovitch (E'24), the anonymous bond script (1924), and the Dormitory Bond (1952) were donated by the Office of Alumni relations. The circa 1920-1930 Tufts College Bond for Howard Edwin Grupe was donated by Paula Coyle in December 2018.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The circa 1920-1930 Tufts College Bond for Howard Edwin Grupe was a gift of Paula Coyle, 2018, accession UA-2019-053.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donor unknown; This item is a player piano music roll; written on the box and music roll is the following "Eighty-Eight Note 300503 Tufts College Medley Overture Introducing: (1) Around the Rez; (2) Aren't You Glad You're a Tufts Man? (3) I've Been Thinking; (4) Brown and Blue; (5) The Jumbo Cantepic; (6) Hymn to College Hill; (7) The Barnum Song; (8) For Tufts, Hurrah!; (9) Keep Your Eye on Tufts; (10) Tufts Victory Song; (11) Dear Alma Mater; (12) Forward, Tufts! Arranged by George Swift"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of Jessica Villella. Screws are included. Accompanying note (included in envelope) says that the plaque was on the door of room 024 in basement of Aidekman and was removed in March 2006 before basement demolition. As of fall 2010, research indicates that room 024 was the Music Library annex but that the plaque predates that use of the room and it is therefore unclear who Edward E. Cohen was and for what the room was dedicated.

did.unittitle: Patches for Peace plaque

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This item is being used in the spring 2012 reunion exhibit. This box contains the plaque that was displayed with the Patches for Peace quilt. The plaque displays the following message: "'Patches for Peace' was a campus-wide effort to respond in a hopeful way to the tragic events of September 11, 2001. Spearheaded by Tufts Hillel, 88 University organizations came together over the following months to construct a 96 square foot quilt that was unveiled on November 7th of the same year. The project symbolizes the united vision for peace the diverse members of the Tufts community share." The plaque also displays a list of the 88 students groups that participated in the Patches for Peace project.

did.unittitle: Patches for Peace quilt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "'Patches for Peace' was a campus-wide effort to respond in a hopeful was to the tragic events of September 11, 2001. Spearheaded by Tufts Hillel, 88 University organizations came together over the following months to construct a 96 square foot quilt that was unveiled on November 7th of the same year. The project symbolizes the united vision for peace the diverse members of the Tufts community share." Source: Patches for Peace plaque. UA136/001-026.00001. Collection documentation folder in UA136 includes a DVD by conservators.

did.unittitle: Rip off ROTC poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This print was found by Facilities with a folder of materials belonging to Dean Katherine Jeffers in the summer of 2010. The origin of this poster is unknown, and there is no indication that it is related to ROTC protests at Tufts. The poster's relationship to Dean Jeffers' posters and prints is also unknown, though Katherine Jeffers' death in 1959 predates any known ROTC protest at Tufts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by University Advancement, 2018, accession UA-2019-051.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains a program for the Tufts College and Brown University Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs (1891); a program for the Banquet for Tufts Men under the auspices of the Tower Cross Society (1912); a photographic clipping of the Tufts football team (circa 1900-1930); a photograph of members of the Tufts baseball team (circa 1900-1930); a Tufts College stamp (circa 1900-1945); a Tufts College Physics Laboratory report (1938-1939); and a Tufts University Police patch (circa 1960-2000).

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This file contains Tufts-related memorabilia and items received by Tufts President Tony Monaco, many donated by Richard Goldstein. These items were given to University Advancement and transferred to DCA in December 2018.

did.unittitle: An act to incorporate the Trustees of Tufts College, Commonwealth of Massachusetts in the year 1852 [College Charter]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This item was found uncatalogued in the stacks in the winter of 2009. It is most likely a copy of the original incorporation certificate passed in the House of Representatives on April 15, 1852 and in the Senate on April 21, 1852; the signatures are represented, but the certificate is not signed; no seals; also included are 'An Act in Addition...' passed May 17, May 19, and May 20, 1852. Note its different location; it is housed in a separate box with other oversize materials. The document is written on vellum.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Edward J. Young, H1887

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harvard graduate (A.B. 1848). Author of "Andrew P. Peabody: A Memoir" and "The Lesson of the Hour." He gave the "Russell Lecture" at Tufts in September 1885 and received an honorary degree from Tufts in 1887. There are three letters from him in a vertical file. A small amount of additional material is held at the Harvard Archives. This photograph was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2007. Note its different location; it is housed in a separate box with other oversize materials. Date is approximate

did.unittitle: Photograph of James D. Perkins, M.D., Honorary Degree recipient

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This date is approximate. This item was found uncataloged in the stacks in the winter of 2009. Note the different location of this item; it is housed in a box with other oversize materials. Perkins received an honorary degree from Tufts in 1903. He subsequently donated $400 to furnish a room in Eaton Memorial Library. It is likely that this photograph once hung in the library.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Hervey A. Hanscom, 97 years old

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This item was found uncataloged in the stacks in the winter of 2009. Note the different location of this item; it is housed in a box with other oversize materials. Hanscom established a scholarship at Tufts in 1954 to be used "to aid a deserving boy, preferably a country boy from the state of Maine and/or the children of employees of Hervey A. Hanscom." Hanscom established similar scholarships at several colleges and universities in New England. He worked in the cement industry and eventually owned his own business, likely based in Medford, MA.

did.unittitle: First class and faculty of Tufts College
Class and faculty of Tufts College
Award to Tufts College from the World's Columbian Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. This award poster is evidence of Tufts College's participation in the college exhibits at the World's Columbian Exhibition in Chicago in 1893. The award states that Tufts' exhibit was an "illustration of college grounds, buildings, course of study, and appliances." They received the award "for excellence of course of study, buildings, and appliances for the work of a New England college." The college exhibits occupied space in the educational section of the Liberal Arts Department in the south gallery of the Manufactures and Liberal Arts Building. Apparently the purpose of these exhibits was to display the educational facilities, courses of study and methods of instruction afforded by the colleges. More information can be found by viewing the "Report of the Massachusetts Board of World's Fair Managers" (Boston, 1894). See also Columbian Exhibition memorabilia in the artifact collection.

scopecontent.p: According to A Century of Excellence by Dr. Henry Banks, The seven founders and original professors of Tufts' medical school are, from left, front row, Dr. John W. Johnson, obstetrics/gynecology; Dr. Charles P. Thayer, anatomy; Dr. Albert Nott, dean, physiology; and Dr. William R. Chipman, surgery. Back row, Dr. Henry W. Dudley, pathology; Dr. Walter L. Hall, medicine; and Dr. Frank G. Wheatley, material medica.

Audio Lab materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains audio and video recordings made by the Audio Lab of lectures, panels, conferences, and performances at Tufts circa 1960-2000. Notable speakers include Ralph Nader, F. Lee Bailey, Robert Klein, Maya Angelou, Noam Chomsky, George McGovern, Dr. Benjamin Spock, Coretta Scott King, Allen Ginsberg, Timothy Leary, Stokely Carmichael, William F. Buckley, Margaret Mead, Muhammed Ali, Jane Fonda, Joe Biden, Norman Mailer, Isaac Asimov, P.J. O'Rourke, Jimmy Carter, Haruki Murakami, Margaret Thatcher, and many other prominent social and political figures. Topics covered include the Vietnam War, sexuality, groundbreakings, convocations, benefits, concerts, and a wide range of other social and political topics including women's, international, and race issues.

These tapes were transferred to Digital Collections and Archives from the Olin Center in 2009. The F.W. Olin Center for Language and Cultural Studies was dedicated and opened in the fall of 1991. Its mission includes the collecting of audio and video recordings of Tufts special events. Prior to 1991 the language and media lab was located in Eaton Hall from 1967-1981, and then Cabot Center from 1981-1991. The collection that now exists seems to be an amalgamation of various distinct series that were carried over from each previous location.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically in several runs by accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 16mm film of "How one College Educates;" also includes VHS tape of "How One College Educates" written by Grant F. Curtis and William P. Saunders, photographed and directed by William P. Saunders; also includes footage which according to the tape is "The following social activities at the Delta Upsilon House filmed by David [A'62] and Linda Adzigian [J'62] during the 1961-1962 school year, and include most of the brothers from the classes of 1962-1965, our dates, our chaperones, and the legendary Sam Sardone. Former barcode 39090011486624gHighlights in order of appearance: -Campus Scenes -1961 Rush Activities -Chi Omega singers in living room -Beatnik Party -Brief Shot of Mrs. Leonard -Playboy Party -Chorus line singing "Fever" -Christmas Formal -St. Patrick's Party and green potato salad -Hell Week -The Original Hawaiian Party -Spring Weekend at the Seacrest -Graduation Class of 1962
